title: Electric vehicle battery production in Europe gets boost thanks to EIB loan of €480 million to LG Chem Wroclaw Energy in Poland
notes:
Location:
- The project is located in south-west Poland, on the industrial site of LG Chem Wroclaw Energy.

Capacity:
- The project will have an annual production capacity of over 35 GWh, potentially powering more than 500,000 zero-emission electric cars per year. There are plans to ramp up the battery capacity output to approximately 65 GWh, making the Polish facility one of the largest lithium-ion cell factories in the world.

Investment amounts:
- The European Investment Bank (EIB) has signed a €480 million loan agreement with LG Chem Wroclaw Energy, covering around a third of the total project costs estimated at €1.5 billion. The remainder will come from the company’s own resources and from other financing sources.

Project progress:
- The project has received a significant loan from the EIB, and the company plans to create a competitive battery value chain in Europe and Poland. The implementation of the new investment program will enable the company to ramp up its battery capacity output and create more than 1,800 jobs at the Wroclaw site by the end of 2022.

Project type:
- The project involves the construction and operation of highly automated and innovative manufacturing facilities for advanced lithium-ion cells and batteries for battery-powered electric vehicles. It includes the development of a fully integrated production system that will make all battery components from electrodes to cells, modules, and packs for the first time in Europe.

Value chain stages:
- The project covers the manufacturing of advanced lithium-ion cells and batteries for battery-powered electric vehicles, including the production of electrodes, cells, modules, and battery packs.

title: LG Chem Wrocław secures 480 million-euro loan to ramp up battery production

title: LG Chem Poland receives a €480 million loan from the European Investment Bank
notes:
Location:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy project is located in Wroclaw, Poland.
- LG Chem's Cheongju cathode material plant is located in South Korea.
- LG Chem's Gumi plant is also located in South Korea.
- LG Chem and Huayou Cobalt's precursor plant is planned to be built in Saemangeum National Industrial Complex, South Korea.
- LG Energy Solutions has signed a MOU with Indonesia for producing EV batteries in Indonesia.
- Ultium Cells LLC, a joint venture with LG Chem, is located in Northeast Ohio, USA.
- LG Chem's Nanjing factory is located in Nanjing, China.

Capacity:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy's production facility will have an annual capacity of over 35 GWh, with plans to ramp up to ca. 65 GWh.
- LG Chem's Cheongju cathode material plant has started mass production of high-nickel single-particle cathode materials for next-generation EV batteries.
- Ultium Cells LLC, a joint venture with LG Chem, will mass-produce Ultium battery cells for electric vehicles and create more than 1,100 new jobs in Northeast Ohio, USA.
- LG Chem's Nanjing factory will focus on long-axis EV batteries.

Investment amounts:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy will receive a €480 million loan from the European Investment Bank (EIB) for the construction and operation of its manufacturing facilities, with total project costs estimated at €1.5 billion.
- LG Chem has announced a plan to invest 10 trillion won by 2025 in battery materials and eco-friendly materials.
- LG Chem and Huayou Cobalt have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to build a precursor plant in Saemangeum National Industrial Complex, South Korea.

Project progress:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy has received a significant loan from the European Investment Bank (EIB) and plans to create over 1,800 jobs at the Wroclaw site by end-2022.
- LG Chem has started mass production of high-nickel single-particle cathode materials for next-generation EV batteries at its Cheongju cathode material plant.
- LG Chem has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with stakeholders to build a precursor plant in Saemangeum National Industrial Complex, South Korea.
- LG Energy Solutions has signed a MOU with Indonesia for producing EV batteries in Indonesia.
- Ultium Cells LLC, a joint venture with LG Chem, is actively hiring for key positions to execute the setup and launch of battery cell manufacturing in Northeast Ohio, USA.
- LG Chem is expanding its Nanjing factory and focusing on long-axis EV batteries.

Project type:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy is a new build project for manufacturing advanced lithium-ion cells and batteries for battery-powered electric vehicles (BEVs).
- LG Chem's Cheongju cathode material plant has started mass production of high-nickel single-particle cathode materials for next-generation EV batteries.
- Ultium Cells LLC, a joint venture with LG Chem, will mass-produce Ultium battery cells for electric vehicles in Northeast Ohio, USA.
- LG Chem is expanding its Nanjing factory and focusing on long-axis EV batteries.

Value chain stages:
- LG Chem Wroclaw Energy's manufacturing facilities will cover cathode and anode manufacturing, cell fabrication, and module assembly.
- LG Chem's Cheongju cathode material plant is involved in cathode material production.
- Ultium Cells LLC, a joint venture with LG Chem, will mass-produce battery cells for electric vehicles.
- LG Chem's Nanjing factory will focus on long-axis EV batteries.

title: 5 years of LG Energy Solution Wrocław - the largest investment in the region
notes:
Location:
- The battery production project is located in Biskupice Podgórne near Wroclaw, in the Wroclaw agglomeration, Poland.

Capacity:
- The project's target production capacity is 100 GWh, with the ongoing stage IV expansion aimed at reaching this capacity. The plant currently occupies an area of over one million square meters.

Investment amounts:
- The investment by LG Energy Solution Wroclaw is exceeding 3 billion euros. The total cost of the investment in Biskupice Podgórne is expected to amount to EUR 3.2 billion.

Project progress:
- The company started operations in 2016, with the production of lithium-ion batteries commencing in the second half of 2017. The plant has been steadily growing over the past 5 years and is currently in the stage IV expansion to reach its target production capacity.

Project type:
- The project is a new build, with the construction of the battery factory beginning in 2016.

Value chain stages:
- The facility covers the stages of cathode and anode manufacturing, cell fabrication, and module assembly.

Note: The project has contributed to Poland becoming the largest exporter of car batteries in the EU, and has led to the country's position as a significant center of innovative technology in the industry.
